member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.CoordinateSystem.CheckConstraints(Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet.Changes)
member.summary: Checks the constraints and throws an exception if the check failed.

remarks.para: The method checks the constraints and throws an exception if the check failed.

The constraint of a coordinate system means reversibility of its every axes' data. Common variable provides an access to its values by an integer index or a vector of indices, but an axis should allow finding an index (or a vector of indices) by a coordinate value from that axis. This is a reversed index selection operation which enables retrieving a value from a variable by its coordinate values in a given coordinate system (see ). The constraint in the one-dimensional case is just a claim for data to be strictly monotonic for numeric and date/time data types, or contain no duplicate values for others (for instance, strings).

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Variable`1
member.summary: Represents a single typed array or a scalar with attached metadata.
member.typeparam: Type of data for the variable.

remarks.para: For type safety and early binding a base class of all variable’s implementations is a generic class , where DataType is a type of an array’s element. To provide a uniform work with variables of unknown or different types, class is derived from a non-generic class . For example, the collection yields objects of the type which then might be casted to the required generic type.
The generic class adds to the basic class method to append a single value and a typed indexer obtaining a single value from the data array.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Variable
member.summary: Represents a single array or a scalar value with attached metadata.

remarks.para: represents a single array or a scalar value with attached metadata. cannot exist separately but always belongs to some instance. Typically, a variable does not completely load all underlying data into memory, and performs on-demand data access. But in common it depends on a particular implementation of a variable which varies for different providers.

Each variable has unique , (optional and not unique), (i.e. type of an element of variable’s array), (number of dimensions of the array), and shape (; lengths of all array’s dimensions). Type of data and rank are specified when variable is created and cannot be modified afterwards. If a variable is not read-only (see ), shape is changing as a user puts data into a variable (i.e. into an underlying array). It is important that the Scientific DataSet model doesn’t limit any dimension, i.e. all dimensions are unbounded. In other words, it is possible to extend a variable by each dimension. But a particular providers still may force extra constraints. Methods should be used to get a recent shape of a variable.

The supports types given in the table below. An attempt to create a variable for a type not listed in the table, leads to an exception . The static method makes dynamic check whether a type is supported or not.
Note that is not supported!

Not read-only variable may be renamed at any time through the property. The property updates the proposed name of the variable, which becomes actual only after committing. To get the proposed name, use accessor for the version.

Besides a name, a variable has an integer that is given on definition and cannot be modified. The ID is unique inside its and can be used for identification of a variable after it’s been renamed. Note that several variables with same name within a are allowed, but the is unique.

As mentioned above, along with an array a variable contains metadata attached to the data. Metadata is a dictionary of keys and values represented as an instance of the class and available through the property. Please see remarks for the class to read about constraints on metadata.
In fact, the name of a variable is just a metadata entry with name defined in . The same is for a missing value. Therefore, properties and just refer the collection.
List of coordinate systems, attached to a variable, is available through the collection.

Method returns entire array of the variables. Methods and return a part of the data. Generic class also has an indexer returning a single value for specified indices:
Variable<int> v = (Variable<int>)dataSet["var"]; int i = v[new int[] { 0 }]; // gets the value at the index { 0 }
Work with metadata.
Use a collection available through the property.
Variable v = dataSet["var"]; v.Metadata["Units"] = "m/s"; . . . string units = (string)v.Metadata["Units"];

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Variable.CheckReversibility(Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.SchemaVersion)
member.summary: Checks whether the variable is reversible.
member.param: Version of the variable to check.
member.returns: Returns true if the variable is reversible.

remarks.para: One of the ScientificDataSet consistency constraints is the constraint on axis data: each axis of numeric and DateTime values must be reversible and an axis of any other type must have no duplicate values. The constraint enables the reversing mechanism which makes it possible to get a value from a variable not only by its indices but also by its coordinate values (for details see remarks for ). The current release of the library provides a mechanism of the constraint check only for one-dimensional axis and only for numeric and DateTime values. This is the only implemented check for performance reasons.
The check is implemented at the level of the class, the base class for all variables. Therefore each variable inherently enables the reversibility check by default.
There are two methods declared as abstract in the class and implemented in the class: public method and internal method .

The method makes a check for the given schema version of the variable and returns either true or false depending whether data is reversible or not. The check is actually performed only for one-dimensional variables having a numeric or DateTime data type. For any other case the method just returns true without a check. The method is called in the commit procedure (at the precommit stage; see remarks for ) as a part of the CheckConstaints logic of the CoordinateSystem class. This means that it is called at the committing for each variable of a data set being an axis. If the method returns false, the check failed.

The current data stored in the data set’s underlying storage is always considered as a consistent, hence when a variable is initialized as an axis on a data set loading, it is also considered as satisfying of all constraints including reversibility without actual check of its persistent data. If the committed variable (that is not an axis) is added as an axis to a coordinate system, then in the next constraint check (i.e. in the nearest commit procedure) all persistent data of the variable is loaded and checked on reversibility. The new data arrays those have been put to the variable are checked during the commit procedure. All these arrays must have the same order and they are also checked in the context of the already committed data (if needed, one value to the left and one to the right of the proposed data array are loaded from the persistent storage and they must be in accordance with the array order itself). The result of the check is cached, so in the next commit the only proposed data arrays are checked.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Variable.GetData(System.Int32[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Gets the data for the variable from specified rectangular region.
member.param: The origin of the rectangle (left-bottom corner). Null means all zeros.
The shape of the rectangle. Null means maximal shape.
member.returns: An array of data from specified rectangle.

remarks.para: A variable is not a data storage itself; it is just a representation of an array and its metadata stored in the underlying data storage, and it provides an on-demand access to that storage. This enables work with very large arrays, stored in some format, when a researcher might need only a part of the data in memory.
To get a committed shape (i.e. vector of lengths by each dimension) of the underlying array the methods should be used.

The method enables retrieving a sub-array of the array. Its parameters specify a rectangle of indices that defines which part of the array should be retrieved. First parameter is an of the rectangle, which is an index vector. Second parameter defines of the rectangle, which is a vector of lengths of the rectangle by each dimension. Lengths of both and parameters must be equal to the of the variable, i.e. the method doesn’t reduce the dimensionality of an array.

Requested rectangle must be less or equal to the entire shape of a variable (). If the is null, it will be considered as a vector of zeros. If the is null, the maximum available shape will be used. For instance, GetData(null, null) returns entire array.
The GetData methods always get committed data, even if the has changes.
For scalar variables and should be either null or has zero length. For scalar variables GetData returns one dimensional array with one item.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Variable.GetData(System.Int32[],System.Int32[],System.Int32[])
member.summary: Gets the data for the variable from specified stridden slices.
member.param: The origin of the rectangle (left-bottom corner). Null means all zeros.
member.returns: An array of data from specified rectangle.

remarks.para: Resulting array contains values from the and has the same as the variable does. Shape of the resulting array is equal to , except when the is null. In this case, the real shape of the stridden array is "as much as possible" depending on the shape of the variable (). If is null, an integer array with all zeros is inferred. The contains a step to stride values of the variable. For 1d variables, value of a stridden variable with the index i corresponds to the value with index start[0] + i*stride[0] of the variable. For multidimensional variables, the principle is similar.
See also remarks for .
For scalar variables , and should be either null or has zero length. For scalar variables GetData returns one dimensional array with one item.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Variable.PutData(System.Int32[],System.Array)
member.summary: Puts the data to the variable starting with specified origin indices.
member.param: Indices to start adding of data. Null means all zeros.
Data to put to the variable.

remarks.para: If a variable is not read-only (see ), then data (that is an array of a correct type and rank) can be put into a variable at any time. All dimensions of a variable are unbounded, so it is possible to extend it by any dimension.
The array is copied by the PutData method, therefore after this method call, it is allowed to change the array without affecting the data of the variable or proposed changes to commit.

Usually, an SDS provider doesn’t write affected changes into the underlying storage immediately (but its behavior still depends on a particular implementation). To perform it, after all planned actions with the are completed, commit changes as described in remarks for .
Important: all arrays as parameters in the PutData methods must have a rank equal to the variable’s rank (see ).
The method of the allows putting an array into variable starting with zero indices.
Another method puts data into a rectangle defined by a shape of a given array and an parameter, which is an index vector of the starting corner of the rectangle to place data in.

If the variable was not empty, then overlapping values are replaced by values from the proposed array. If new array is larger than existing, variable’s shape is extended. In this case, there can be areas those are not overlapped by both existing data and proposed.
Append methods allow appending an array to existing data. See more in remarks for .
For scalar variables should be either null or has zero length. Array should be one dimensional array containing one item.

example.para: Don’t forget either commit changes to make them actual or enable autocommit (see ).

member.exception: Cannot put data into the variable.

member.summary: Puts the data to the variable starting with zero indices.
member.param: Data to add to the variable.

remarks.para: Append methods allow appending an array to existing data. The simplest version of the method accepts only an array and appends a variable by its first dimension (i.e. a dimension with index 0).
The other Append methods allow to specify either index of a dimension to append by or its name (if dimensions names have been explicitly specified on a definition of the variable, see remarks for ).
All changes becomes actual only after committing ().
The array is copied by the method, therefore after this method call, it is allowed to change the array without affecting the data of the variable or proposed changes to commit.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet
member.summary: Facilitates creating, reading and modifying of a scientific data set.

remarks.para: The is a top-level class of the Scientific DataSet library that is aimed to provide a single data model for different scientific data sets. Applications are able to store and retrieve data uniformly, having an abstract view on various custom data storages. This makes an application less dependent on data formats and significantly eases data transfer between software components.

The bundles several related arrays and associated metadata in a single self-descriptive package and enforces certain constraints on arrays' shapes to ensure data consistency. An underlying data model of the is based on a long-term community experience. The SDS Data Model has commonality to the Unidata’s Common Data Model, being chosen since CDM has been successfully tested by time.
Particular implementation, providing an access to the specified data storage, is chosen on a basis of the URI. Such implementation named provider.
Current release contains following providers:

A provider might have extra parameters specified in the URI. For example, it can be security credentials, behavioral properties etc. For more information see documentation of a particular provider. To customize a URI prior to opening a , use capabilities exposed by the class.

Relationships between variables are expressed using a concept of shared dimensions. A DataSet dimension is a distinct named index space. For example, saying that variable Observation shares the dimension with variable X we mean that Observation[i] relate somehow to X[i] for all indices i from the shared index space. Additionally this introduces a constraint to the : the lengths of these two variables must always be the same.
In common the rule says that lengths of a shared dimension for all variables, depending on it, must be equal.
In addition to metadata attached to each , there is a global metadata attached to the (see ). Metadata is a dictionary of string keys and typed values, represented as a class.
The instance can be read-only (see ). Such cannot be modified.
The uses two-phase transaction mechanism to commit changes. See remarks for the method for details. See also remarks for the property.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet.Open(System.String)
member.summary: Opens connection to a for the specified .

remarks.para:
The method uses the class that enables creating an instance of a particular provider on a basis of the . The URI is either a file path (with possible parameters appended through '?') or a URI with schema "msds" and correct provider name and set of parameters. See also class.
For example, provider accepts following URIs:
c:\data\test.csv c:\data\test.csv?openMode=createNew msds:csv?file=c:\data\test.csv&openMode=createNew
The URI "msds:nc?file=c:\data.test.csv" will cause an error for it has wrong provider name ("nc" instead of "csv").

A provider should have the attribute specifying a provider name. There might also be declared attributes to associate extensions with the provider, and to associate a concrete type with the provider (see also ).
[DataSetProviderName("csv")] [DataSetProviderFileExtension(".csv")] [DataSetProviderUriTypeAttribute(typeof(CsvUri))] public class CsvDataSet : DataSet
The class has property returning a URI of a instance.
For developers: there is a class implementing basic functionality on parsing and verifying DataSet URIs and it should be used to embed the support of URI to DataSet provider.
See also remarks for .

member.summary: Creates new and adds it to the .
member.param: Type of data for the variable.
List of names of the variable's dimensions.

remarks.para: See list of supported types in remarks for the class.

New variable can be defined and added into a at any time (obviously, this procedure changes the schema of a ). The creating and adding of a variable are performed as a single operation by AddVariable methods of the class. These methods accept at least a name of a variable, its type and dimensions, and return new variable instance.

Parameters and can be null. A rank of the variable (i.e. a number of dimensions) is either equal to the rank of (if it is not a null) or a length of the . Initial data of the new variable is an . If both array and dims are nulls (or is an empty array), then the variable is a scalar, i.e. has rank zero (read more in remarks for ).
The is copied by the method, therefore after this method call, it is allowed to change the array without affecting the data of the variable or proposed changes to commit.

example.para: Let’s get an example of the methods use:
In the example, three one-dimensional variables A, B and C are added to the given instance. All variables depends on same dimension named "x". The property defines corresponded metadata entry.

remarks.para: The very important is that the class sets relations between added variables. The rule is: all dimensions of different variables with same name are considered as related (i.e. they share same dimension). This means that values with equal indices by related dimensions in different variables are considered as corresponded, and lengths of related dimensions in different variable must be equal. See about constraints on data.

Therefore in the given example all arrays depend on the same dimension named "x". This leads to the constraint when lengths of A, B and C must be equal, and A, for instance, can be an axis for B and C.
Dimension name is an arbitrary string, used only to specify which dimensions of different variables are related.
of a variable is computed as a number of specified dimensions. Thus all dimensions must be given.

example.para: In this example, variables lat and lon are one-dimensional, pressure is two-dimensional variable, and a pair lon and pressure (by first dimension), and another pair lat and pressure (by second dimension) depend on a same dimension. In other words, values pressure[i,j] corresponds to both lon[i] and lat[j].

remarks.para: The constraint on variables requests that their dimensions with same name must have same length.

member.summary: Creates a reference variable.
member.param: If not null, defines dimensions of the variable within this .
member.returns: Reference variable to the given variable.

remarks.para: It is prohibited to create a reference to a variable from the same .
If is null or an empty array, the reference variable has the same dimensions, as the does.

Reference variable is a special kind of variables whose purpose is to refer another variable. All requests to data and metadata are translated to corresponding requests for the underlying variable. Changes to underlying variable generate corresponding events for the reference variable, etc. Both target and reference variables share the metadata collection. Names of dimensions and coordinate systems can change independently and don't cause another variable to be changed.

If a has incoming or outcoming reference, it is linked to another and they can be committed only together (i.e. "distributed" commit happens). The property gets the value indicating whether the has incoming or outcoming references or not. The method returns list of linked DataSets.

member.exception: References within the DataSet are prohibited.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet.GetSchema(Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.SchemaVersion)
member.summary: Gets the specified version of schema.
member.param: Version of the schema to get.
member.returns: Specified version of schema of the .
member.remarks: If the is modified (see property), it has two versions of the schema. First is a committed schema (the version named ), second is a proposed schema (the version named ). The committed schema describes the actual content of the underlying storage and always satisfies the constraints. The proposed schema may not to satisfy constraints and is being accumulated as a user modifies the (if the is false). After sucessful , the proposed schema becomes committed. Version corresponds to the proposed version, if it exists; or to the committed version, otherwise.

member.summary: Checks constraints and if the check succeeds, commits all recent changes.
member.returns: If commit succeeds, returns true; otherwise, returns false or throws an exception.

remarks.para: If commit succeeds, returns true. If commit is failed because of failed constraints check, returns false; otherwise, throws an exception describing the failure reason. See also method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet.Commit
member.summary: Checks constraints and if the check succeeds, commits all recent changes.

remarks.para: Two-phase transaction mechanism is used to commit the or a number of linked by reference variables s (see also ). This approach guarantees that persistent data are always in a consistent state, i.e. satisfy required constraints. The rule says that all variables sharing a dimension must have equal length by that dimension. The dimensions are shared between two or more variables if they have same name. Dimensions names are specified when a is added to the (see ).

If any changes are made in a schema or data of a , these changes are accumulated until a user tries to commit them. Therefore, if a has any changes (see ), there are two versions of a schema available in the (see ): first is a committed schema (it is always consistent) and second is a proposed schema (it has no constraints); see also . of proposed changes can succeed only if all constraints are satisfied; in this case proposed changes become new consistent state of the . If the check fails, a user can either try to fix changes or to a previous consistent state.

To ease the work with the , the autocommitting capability is added and is enabled by default (see property). When it is enabled, the tries to commit after every change of the . Consider disable it to increase the performance.
If constraints check fails, the method throws exception with information about the fault.
See also method and property .

remarks.para: The method creates a stridden variable, implementing the interface , and returns it. The stridden variable has the same type as the does. The values of that variable are taken from .
Subsetting parameters for a stridden variable are: , , . They are defined when a variable is created. Length of the parameters must be equal to the rank of the source variable.

item.description: origin == null: all start indices are zeros;
count == null: all dimensions of a stridden variable are unlimited and depend on the source variable;
stride == null: stride is 1 for all dimensions;
count[i] == 0: i-th dimension is unlimited and always is equal to the length of the source variable;
stride[j] == 0: removes dimension j from result, corresponding count[j] must be 1.

remarks.para: The method creates for a stridden variable new dimensions with unique complex name, except for the case when origin=0, stride=1, count=0 (i.e. the dimension is not strided); in this case the stridden variable depends on the same dimension as the source variable does.

Parameters of the striding are reflected in the of the stridden variable. Attribute names are available through const fields of the class . Metadata attribute "indexSpaceOrigin" of type int[] describes starting indices for stridden variable.
change of the origin parameter must not lead to change of the stridden variable's shape. The reason is that a shape of any variable can grow only. Therefore, a stridden variable can grow only if the source variable grows.
value indexSpaceOrigin[i] is changeable only if corresponding count[i] > 0 (so that the shape of a stridden variable is fixed and cannot change).
If a value of the indexSpaceOrigin is incorrect, the will fail.

Metadata attributes "indexSpaceStride" and "indexSpaceCount" contain arrays of strides and counts respectively, thus describing parameters of the striding. This are the read only attributes that never change (otherwise they would change the shape).
Metadata attribute "indexSpaceSourceDims" contains an array of dimension names of the source variable, corresponding to origin indices. This is the read only attribute that never changes.
Stridden variable implements . The interface can be used to imperatively update the origin parameter. See method .
Changes to the underlying variable are reflected in the stridden variable, but not vice versa. Hence a stridden variable is always read-only.
If the is null, the name of the output variable will be the same as the name of the input variable .
Both source and target variable share the metadata collection. But some attributes can be separated or markes as read-only for a stridden variable. See parameters and .

The third line contains unique identifier of the instance (see ).

Below goes a list of variables. Each variable summary shows variable , , and shape (see also ). Variable shape includes one dimension for vectors, two dimensions for matrices etc. Variable summary shows both name and length for each of the dimensions.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet.GetMultipleData(Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataRequest[])
member.summary: Gets data from several variables atomically with a guarantee that the data belong to the same DataSet version.
member.param: Data requests describing what data is to be returned.

remarks.para: The problem is to get consistent data from one version of a DataSet. A typical program flow for working with data from several related variables involve several consequent calls of the . If the data set is being changed in the background by another process, the data returned may come from different versions (see ). This is inappropriate for many applications.
The solution is to use method which performs several operations atomically and guarantees that all returned arrays belong to the same DataSet version.

member.exception: or one of its elements is null.

Version of the DataSet unexpectedly changed during getting data.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet.Metadata
member.summary: Gets the metadata attached to the .

remarks.para: The property gets the global attached to the DataSet.

To developers of a custom provider: internally the global metadata dictionary is stored as a zero-rank variable of type with equal to . Creating of such variable can be delegated to the constructor or performed by the custom provider itself (see constructor ). The property just refers the dictionary of that variable. Also the variable is hidden and doesn't include it in a common enumeration list and value. To enumerate through all variables, use property. Nevertheless, the variable is presented in the .

member.name: P:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet.IsAutocommitEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets the value indicating whether the autocommit is enabled.

remarks.para: The property is initialized with true at the construction. Please consider following remarks and think about turning it off.

The uses two-phase transaction mechanism to commit accumulated changes. It is described in remarks for the method. But the enables an option named "autocommitting" to simplify a code working with a . If the property is true, an instance of the provider tries to commit itself on every change. Therefore, if the proposed schema satisfies all constraints, the becomes committed; otherwise, it continues to be modifed until a change satisfies constraints.

The use of the autocomitting option is convenient but less effecient comparing to manual committing. The reason is that manual commit allows to save a number of accumulated changes as one and once; autocommitting may lead to series of saving, each of them is usually an expensive operation. This can significantly decrease performance, depending on a particular provider type. Also autocomitting can prevent from using in some cases as it makes it possible to roll back only changes accumulated since last erroneous change, i.e. change that broke constraints (see example below for demonstration). Therefore, autocomitting should be turned off for complex tasks.

When using autocomitting, there is a way to find out whether the is committed or not after any change: it is the property that should be checked (see the example below). If the is not committed, but expected to be, it is still possible to get the problem description by an explicit call of the method and catching an exception.

member.summary: Gets the read-only collection of objects.

remarks.para: The property returns the read-only collection of variables, including both committed and proposed variables at the moment of the property access. In other words, if a variable is added to the right after the collection is returned by this property, new variable is not contained in the collection.

The returned collection provides special logic to work separately with different schema versions. By default, without an explicit specification, the collection provides an access to the committed version only.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Factory.DataSetFactory
member.summary: Facilitates creating a instance from a URI.

remarks.para: is designated to enable creating a instance for a particular provider from a special URI (see ).
The type enables a customization of a URI prior to creating a DataSet. See for details.

Any DataSet provider must be registered in the factory first to enable its instances to be created by the method. Attribute , applied to a DataSet provider type, associate it with a provider name. Attribute associates a provider type with one or severial extensions. Attribute associates a provider type with a type derived from the that provides a customization of its URI.
The factory control class is a static class . The class allows registering of providers and creating new instances. The class is used by the and methods.

There are three ways to register providers. First is a DataSetFactory.Register group of methods. These methods allow both to register provider names and associate extensions to a particular provider. The methods intensively use mentioned attributes and
in the process.

example.para: For example, the provider can be registered in this way:
example.code: DataSetFactory.Register(typeof(NetCDFDataSet));
DataSetFactory.RegisterAssembly("Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.NetCDF4.dll");

remarks.para:
Third way to register provider is to add registration entry to configuration file (Requires presence of the Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Configuration assembly).
Example of configuration part is given below
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <!-- Declare configuration section named Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.1.3 (this name is required) --> <configSections> <section name="Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.1.3" type="Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Factory.FactoryConfigurationSection, Microsoft.Research.Science.Data" /> <!-- Declarations of other config sections --> </configSections> <Microsoft.Research.Science.Data> <factories> <!-- Register factory by name --> <add name="myProvider" type="MyNamespace.DbxFactory, MyAssembly"/> <!-- Register factory by extension --> <add ext=".dat" type="MyNamespace.DatProvider, MyAssembly"/> </factories> </Microsoft.Research.Science.Data> </configuration>
Registration by name is similar to invocation of . Registration by extension is similar to invocation of .

The core SDS assembly Microsoft.Research.Science.Data includes several providers: msds:memory (flat memory storage, ), msds:memory2 (chunked memory storage, ), msds:csv (CSV file, ), msds:nc (NetCDF, ), and remoting providers: msds:wcf (), msds:remoting ().

When the factory is first accessed, it loads provider registration information from the application configuration files. After that it registers the built-in providers, if they are not registered by the configuration files yet.

member.summary: Registers the provider in the factory.
member.returns: Returns true if the provider is registered.

remarks.para: Registers the name of the provider and its acceptable extensions in the factory.

The name of the provider is taken from its attribute . If the provider type contains several attributes all the names specified will be pended for the provider to be registered with. If the type has no attribute of this type no exception will be thrown. If the name is already registered in the factory the registration for the provider will be silently skipped and the method will return false.
About extensions registering see remarks for the method .

remarks.para: The method creates a instance based on the . If the uri contains schema definition (i.e. starts with "msds:") the factory tries to find a corresponded provider type from the registered providers table (see method ). If the provider is not registered, an exception will be thrown.

If the uri has no schema definition, the string is considered as a path and the factory looks for provider by the extension of the given path (see method ). If there are more than one providers associated with the extension, they will be constructed one by one until the data set is created successfully.
If the is null or an empty string, an instance of the is created.
See also remarks for the class.

member.exception: DataSet is not registered in the factory.
Particular DataSet provider has thrown an exception at construction.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSetUri
member.summary: The class represents a special kind of URI that is a DataSet identification string.

remarks.para: DataSet URI consists of mandatory URI schema ‘msds’ and SDS followed by optional provider parameters. The identification string has following syntax:
msds:provider-name?param1=value1&param2=value2&...#include-var1,include-var2
More formally the URI format is:
DataSetURI ::= msds:provider[?parameters][#include-vars]
provider-name ::= identifier
parameters ::= parameters&parameters|parameter-name=parameter-value
include-vars := variable-name|variable-name,include-vars
parameter-name ::= identifier
parameter-value ::= character-string
Provider-identifier and set of parameter-names depends on a particular data set provider. Please note that the parameters string can contain duplicate parameter names.
A list of supported parameters depends on which provider name is specified in a URI. When a URI is parsed, all parameters, those are not supported by the particular provider, are ignored.
Note that DataSet URI is case-sensitive.
Examples of DataSet URIs are "msds:csv?file=c:\data\test.csv", "msds:as?server=(local)&database=ActiveStorage&integrated security=true&GroupName=mm5&UseNetcdfConventions=true".
The class makes verification and parsing of DataSet URIs and provides methods to access parameters of the given URI. It should be used by provider implementators to parse DataSet URI.
A DataSet provider might have a related special type derived from describing its parameters. This enables customization of a URI through such class before creating the instance. See and .
Read also about DataSet factoring here .

member.name: P:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSetUri.OpenMode
member.summary: Gets the open resource mode.

remarks.para: The property gets the value representing the flag "openMode" in the data set URI.
The flag "openMode" specifies how the data set should open a file, data base or whatever resource it uses to store the data.

Possible values for the flag are (case-sensitive):
Mode Description
createNew Specifies that the data set should create new resource. If the resource already exists, an exception IOException is thrown.
open Specifies that the data set should open an existing resource. If the resource does not exist, an exception ResourceNotFoundException is thrown.
create Specifies that the data set should create a new resource. If the resource already exists, it will be re-created.
openOrCreate Specifies that the data set should open a resource if it exists; otherwise, a new resource should be created.

example.code: DataSet dataSet = DataSet.Open("msds:nc?file=data.nc&openMode=open"); DataSet dataSet = DataSet.Open("msds:as?server=(local)&database=ActiveStorage&integrated security=true&GroupName=mm5&UseNetcdfConventions=true&openMode=createNew");

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.TransformationVariable`2
member.summary: Represents an abstract computational variable performing a reversible or non-reversible transformation of a single source variable.
member.typeparam: Type of data for the underlying variable.
Type of data for the output variable.

remarks.para: TransformationVariable "mirrors" the data in underlying variable. All requests to data translate to corresponding requests for underlying variable. Changes to underlying variable generate corresponding events for the transformation variable, etc.

If transformation is reversible, the data is "mirrored" in both ways. Calls to Variable.PutData() overloads or setting the Variable[indices] property translate to corresponding changes of underlying variable data.

Metadata of the underilying variable propagate to metadata for the TransformationVariable except some certain entries, name and the provenance being an example of such exception. Therefore, changes of the replicated entries in this variable update the same entries in the underlying variable and vice versa. The extra parameters in the constuctor allow specifying the list of independent entries. See more in remarks for the constructor.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.MetadataDictionary.AsReadOnly
member.summary: Wraps committed elements of the metadata collection into new read-only instance of the class.
member.returns: Read-only instance containg same inner collection.

remarks.para: The returned metadata collection and the current one share the same inner collection of the committed elements. Therefore, after the source metadata collection is committed, new elements become available from the returned instance.
The goal of the method is to create a read-only copy of the existing metadata collection that is always up-to-date.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Range
member.summary: Represents non-negative integer range with stride.

remarks.para:
An instance of the struct can be instantiated using static methods of the class:
Single index to choose.
A range of indices from "from" up to "to".
A range of indices with specified step.
A range of indices from "from" up to the maximum index for a given dimension.
A range of indices from "from" up to the maximum index for a given dimension with the specified step.
Single index to choose and reduce this dimension so that the rank of the resulting array is less than the rank of the variable is read from.
Ranges are used in the procedural API available as extensions methods for the class. See .
Negative count means that it is unlimited.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.RefVariable`1
member.summary:
RefVariable is a special kind of variables whose purpose is to refer another variable.
It enables adding of a variable to not native data set. Data operation applied to the reference are translated to the target variable. Both target and reference variables share the data changing as the change of its inner state. Both target and reference variables share the metadata collection. Names of dimensions might change independently and don't cause another variable to be changed. RefVariable allows to extend a collection of coordinate systems of the target variable with its own coordinate system.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Imperative.DataSetExtensions
member.summary: Provides a set of extensions methods enabling work with in a way close to a procedural API.

remarks.para: The goal of the extensions is to enable simple data operations with minimum amount of code. Additionally, it unifies the API with other languages like C, R, Python etc. Note that these are just helper methods which will in fact call universal object model API.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Imperative.DataSetExtensions.Add``1(Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet,System.String,``0,System.String[])
member.summary: Creates new variable with initial data and adds it to the data set.
member.typeparam: An array of variable rank and data type, or a type for scalar variable.

remarks.para: If are absent, the type parameter must be an array type of proper rank. E.g. ds.Add<double[,]>("mat", new double[,]{{1},{2}}) creates a variable named "mat" of type double and of rank 2.

It is still possible to specify type parameter and dimensions of the variable: ds.Add<double[,]>("mat", new double[,]{{1},{2}}, "x", "y") also creates a variable named "mat" of type double and of rank 2. The syntax ds.Add<double>("mat", new double[,]{{1},{2}}, "x", "y") is incorrect, but ds.Add<double>("mat", 10.0) creates a scalar variable with value 10.

If the parameter is an array, it is copied by the method for further use; therefore after this method call, it is allowed to change the original array without affecting the data of the variable or proposed changes to commit.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Imperative.DataSetExtensions.Add``1(Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet,System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Creates new variable and adds it to the data set.
member.typeparam: A variable data type or an array of variable rank and data type.

remarks.para: If are absent, the type parameter must be an array type of proper rank. E.g. ds.Add<double[,]>("mat") creates a variable named "mat" of type double and of rank 2.

It is still possible to specify just type parameter and dimensions of the variable: ds.Add<double>("mat", "x", "y") also creates a variable named "mat" of type double and of rank 2. The syntax ds.Add<double[,]>("mat", "x", "y") is correct, too.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Imperative.DataSetExtensions.PutData``1(Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet,System.String,``0,Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Range[])
member.summary: Puts a range of values into a variable.
member.typeparam: D must a scalar or an array of a proper rank.
member.param: of the variable to get data from.
Range of the data to set.

remarks.para: Number of elements must be equal to the rank of a variable.
Type is a type of the input data. Its rank depends on rank of the variable and how many "reduce" ranges are presented in the (see also ).
can be created using static methods of the class. Read remarks for the struct.
The method finds a variable with name , given rank and type of data (determined from the arguments) and gets the data from it. If a variable is not found, an exception is thrown.

If the parameter is an array, it is copied by the method for further use; therefore after this method call, it is allowed to change the original array without affecting the data of the variable or proposed changes to commit.

example.code: // Let variable "var2d" has rank 2 ds.PutData<double[]>( "var2d", new double[] { 1, 2, 3 }, DataSet.Range(0,2), // 1st dim: from 0 to 2 DataSet.ReduceDim(1)); // 2nd dim is reduced in the input data set and its index is 1

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Imperative.DataSetExtensions.AddAxis(Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet,System.String,System.String,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates new uniform axis variable of type double and adds it to the dataset.
member.param: Units of measurement of values of the axis.
Step of values for the axis.

remarks.para: Adds new axis to the dataset, which is a 1d-variable depending on a dimension with name equal to the variable name, and sets its "Units" attribute to given units string. Values for the axis are uniform and are defined by a user using min,max and step values, so that value[i] = min + step * i.
If the dataset already contains a variable with given name, the method just returns that variable, if it has proper type, rank and units. Values are not checked.

Axis is a 1d-variable with name equal to its dimension name. Example: variable "lat" depending on dimension "lat" is an axis. Coordinate system is a set of axes of a dataset. Can be defined as a list of the variables names in any order. Example: "lat,lon,time", if variables lat,lon,time are axes of a dataset. Methods allow to get value from a variable defined in a coordinate system from its coordinates instead of indices.
DataSet has a default coordinate system which consists from all presented axes. If no dimensions or axes are given when adding new variable (), default coordinate system is chosen, if appropriate.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Imperative.DataSetExtensions.Add``1(Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet,System.String,System.String,``0,System.String[])
member.summary: Creates new variable with given initial data and adds it to the data set.
member.typeparam: An array of variable rank and data type, or a type for scalar variable.

remarks.para: If are absent, the type parameter must be an array type of proper rank. E.g. ds.Add<double[,]>("mat", new double[,]{{1},{2}}) creates a variable named "mat" of type double and of rank 2 in a default coordinate system. If there is no default coordinate system, an exception is thrown.

Axis is a 1d-variable with name equal to its dimension name. Example: variable "lat" depending on dimension "lat" is an axis. Coordinate system is a set of axes of a dataset. Can be defined as a list of the variables names in any order. Example: "lat,lon,time", if variables lat,lon,time are axes of a dataset. Methods allow to get value from a variable defined in a coordinate system from its coordinates instead of indices.
DataSet has a default coordinate system which consists from all presented axes. If no dimensions or axes are given when adding new variable (), default coordinate system is chosen, if appropriate.

It is still possible to specify type parameter and dimensions of the variable: ds.Add<double[,]>("mat", new double[,]{{1},{2}}, "x", "y") also creates a variable named "mat" of type double and of rank 2. The syntax ds.Add<double>("mat", new double[,]{{1},{2}}, "x", "y") is incorrect, but ds.Add<double>("mat", 10.0) creates a scalar variable with value 10.

If the parameter is an array, it is copied by the method for further use; therefore after this method call, it is allowed to change the original array without affecting the data of the variable or proposed changes to commit.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Imperative.DataSetExtensions.Add``1(Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet,System.String,System.String,System.Object,``0,System.String[])
member.summary: Creates new variable with initial data and adds it to the data set.
member.typeparam: An array of variable rank and data type, or a type for scalar variable.
member.param: Missing value that is used within the data.

remarks.para: If are absent, the type parameter must be an array type of proper rank. E.g. ds.Add<double[,]>("mat", new double[,]{{1},{2}}) creates a variable named "mat" of type double and of rank 2.

It is still possible to specify type parameter and dimensions of the variable: ds.Add<double[,]>("mat", new double[,]{{1},{2}}, "x", "y") also creates a variable named "mat" of type double and of rank 2. The syntax ds.Add<double>("mat", new double[,]{{1},{2}}, "x", "y") is incorrect, but ds.Add<double>("mat", 10.0) creates a scalar variable with value 10.

If the parameter is an array, it is copied by the method for further use; therefore after this method call, it is allowed to change the original array without affecting the data of the variable or proposed changes to commit.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Imperative.DataSetExtensions.Add``1(Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet,System.String,System.String,System.Object,``0,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Creates new variable with initial data and adds it to the data set.
member.typeparam: An array of variable rank and data type, or a type for scalar variable.
member.param: Axes of the variable defining the coordinate system.

remarks.para: Axis is a 1d-variable with name equal to its dimension name. Example: variable "lat" depending on dimension "lat" is an axis. Coordinate system is a set of axes of a dataset. Can be defined as a list of the variables names in any order. Example: "lat,lon,time", if variables lat,lon,time are axes of a dataset.
The method adds new variable with given units and missing value. The variable will be defined in a coordinate system containing all given axes.

If the parameter is an array, it is copied by the method for further use; therefore after this method call, it is allowed to change the original array without affecting the data of the variable or proposed changes to commit.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.Imperative.DataSetExtensions.Add``1(Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.DataSet,System.String,System.String,System.Object,``0)
member.summary: Creates new variable with initial data in a default coordinate system and adds it to the data set.
member.typeparam: An array of variable rank and data type, or a type for scalar variable.
member.param: Missing value that is used within the data.

remarks.para: Axis is a 1d-variable with name equal to its dimension name. Example: variable "lat" depending on dimension "lat" is an axis. Coordinate system is a set of axes of a dataset. Can be defined as a list of the variables names in any order. Example: "lat,lon,time", if variables lat,lon,time are axes of a dataset.

The method adds new variable with given units and missing value. The variable will be defined in a default coordinate system, which is a coordinate system consisting of all axes that already present in the DataSet (i.e. of 1d-variables whose name equal to their dimension's name). The order of axes in the coordinate system is found automatically, if possible, depending on a shape of the given and lengths of the axes. Otherwise, if it is impossible to unamigiously identify the correspondence (including case when an array has at least two equal lengths along different dimensions), an exception will be thrown.

If the parameter is an array, it is copied by the method for further use; therefore after this method call, it is allowed to change the original array without affecting the data of the variable or proposed changes to commit.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.CSV.CsvDataSet
member.summary: A provider that stores data in a delimited text file as a flat table.

remarks.para: The provider stores data in a delimited text file as a flat table; in particular the CSV file format is supported. CSV stands for Comma Separated Values. Classic CSV file is a text file that represents data as a table, where each line corresponds to a row in the table. Columns within a line are separated by commas. CSV files are convenient for they are human readable and supported by many applications, including Microsoft Excel.

The provider extends the described file format. First, it supports different delimeters (comma, semicolon, tab and space; see URI parameter "separator"). Second, it may append an output file by another tables (separated by empty lines from the main data table; see URI parameter "appendMetadata"). These extra tables contain information about data stucture and metadata (see also ).

First line of a file contains display names of variables. Use the "noHeader" or "saveHeader" parameters of a URI to change it. If the file doesn't contain metadata table and thus do not define variable's names explicitly, display names also are used as names of the variables.

The provider supports variables of any non-negative rank. Two-dimensional variables are stored as several consequent columns within a file (first index is a row, second index is a column). Only first column of these columns has header; other headers corresponding to the variable are empty. This rule is a criteria of a multidimensional variable within an input file. But if the first column in a file is empty, the corresponding variable is always considered as one-dimensional.

Three and more dimensional variables are also stored as several consequent columns. The rule is: last index corresponds to columns, the preceding index corresponds to rows, and other indices are placed consequently in rows below (last indices vary faster).
The provider is associated with the provider name "csv" and extensions ".csv" and ".tsv" (read about the DataSet factory: ).
About an input and output files encodings please refer a description of a URI parameter "utf8bom" in the table below.

accepts following parameters in a URI (read about DataSet URIs here: ; about preliminary URI customization ):
Parameter Description
file Specifies the file to open or create. This can be either a local file path or a HTTP URL. Examples: "msds:csv?file=c:\data\data.csv", "msds:csv?file=http://arca7.wdcb.ru/DataExplorer/data.csv". If the HTTP URL is specified, the file must exist and the constructed data set is always read only. If there is a need to modify it, consider cloning it into a . See .
openMode=createNew|create|open|openOrCreate|readOnly
The flag "openMode" specifies how the data set should open a file, data base or whatever resource it uses to store the data. Possible values for the flag are:
Mode Description
createNew Specifies that the data set should create new resource. If the resource already exists, an exception IOException is thrown.
open Specifies that the data set should open an existing resource. If the resource does not exist, an exception ResourceNotFoundException is thrown.
readOnly Specifies that the data set should open an existing resource for reading only. If the resource does not exist, an exception ResourceNotFoundException is thrown.
create Specifies that the data set should create a new resource. If the resource already exists, it will be re-created.
openOrCreate Specifies that the data set should open a resource if it exists; otherwise, a new resource should be created.
If the target is read only or is a HTTP URL, the constructed DataSet is always read only. Consider cloning it into a to modify. See .
appendMetadata=true|false If the value is true, the provider appends an output file with special metadata tables, describing structure of the DataSet. These tables can be a reason of incompatibility for some CSV-oriented programs. In this case set the parameter value to false. If the parameter is not specifed, metadata will be appended only if the input file have had metadata appended.
noHeader=true|false If the parameter is false, the first line of an input file is a header containing display names of variables. Otherwise, first line contains data. Note that this parameter doesn't affect an output file. See also parameter "saveHeader". Default is false (i.e. an input file must have a header line).
saveHeader=true|false
Parameter defines whether the provider must save a header line into an output file or not. If it is not specified, its value depends on the "noHeader" parameter: if the input file has no header, the header is not saved in the output file, too; and vice versa.
fillUpMissingValues=true|false Indicates whether the CSV provider should interpreter empty values (i.e. empty strings between separators) in an input file as missing values or not. Default is false.
inferInt=true|false If the value is true, the CSV provider infers following types on loading: int, double, DateTime, string. Otherwise, only double, DateTime and string are inferred. Default is false.
culture The culture name that is used to parse an input file. Default is an invariant culture. Note that this parameter does not affect an output file for it is written for an invariant culture always. Example: "msds:csv?file=data-gb.csv&culture=en-GB".
inferDims=true|false
If the value is true, when parsing a file, all variables (that have no metadata defined for them) with same length are considered as sharing same dimensions. Default is false.
In the following example, if the inferDims is true, variables a and c depend on same dimension; b and d also depend on same dimension, different than the former one. If the inferDims is false, all variables depend on different dimensions.
a b c d 1 10 100 string1 2 20 200 string2 3 300
utf8bom=true|false If utf8bom parameter is defined and is equal to
true, output encoding is UTF8 with signature;
false, output encoding is UTF8 without signature.
If the parameter utf8bom is not defined, and if a file exists, its encoding is kept for an output, otherwise, if the underlying file is created, UTF8 with signature is used.
separator=comma|semicolon|space|tab Determines a char that separates values in the file. Default is "comma".
include The parameter allows including variables as references from another DataSet, that is defined as a URI, into this DataSet. Note, that only variable names conforming C# or Python 3 naming rules, can be specified in the include parameter. Example: msds:memory?include=msds%3Acsv%3Ffile%example.csv%23lat%2Clon (escaped version of "msds:memory?include=escape[msds:csv?file=example.csv#lat,lon]") includes variables lat and lon from msds:csv?file=example.csv. If variables names are not specified, all variables are included.
The provider supports URIs containing a path and appended through '?' parameters: c:\data\air0.csv?openMode=open&fillUpMissingValues=true&inferInt=true.

CsvDataSet provides a special metadata attribute with a key "csv_column". This value is an integer zero-based number of a column within a file that corresponds a variable. For multidimensional variables those are spead on several columns, this value is an index of its first column. A "csv_column" attribute is generated automatically when dataset is loaded. If a file already contains a "csv_column" attribute for some variables, these attributes are ignored and a warning is traced.
A "csv_column" attribute is writable, but now its modification doesn't affects output file. It will be taken into account in future releases.

The CsvDataSet saves variables using the following format string: "yyyy-MM-dd hh:mm:ss" (e.g. "1999-04-20 14:10:00"), acceptable by Microsoft Excel. But this DateTime format provides a precision to within a second. If greater precision is required, it is possible to store using a variable of type .

member.name: P:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.CSV.CsvDataSet.IntegersInTypeInferringEnabled
member.summary: Gets the value indicating whether the type inferring mechanism has used integers (System.Int32) or not during the lading process.
member.remarks: For comatibility it is often convenient not to infer numbers as integers, but as doubles, since 1,2,3 are also 1.0,2.0,3.0 and there is a chance that a user awaits doubles and the type inferer will considers them as integers, that leads to a type mismatch exception. So, if this property is set to false, the most common type - double - is used in any of this case (i.e. 1,2,3 will be considered as doubles). If a user is confident that all numbers are integers it is still possible to set the property to true. Default value is false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.CSV.CsvDataSet.EnableFlatVariables
member.summary: Gets or sets the values indicating whether to save multidimensional variables as flat table or transform it into a single column.

remarks.para: Flat representation of 2d variables uses serveral columns to store the single array:

In the example, A and C are one-dimensional variables, and B is a variable with shape 2 rows x 3 columns. To indicate a flat variable, its first column has a header text ("B") but following columns have empty headers. If the first column has empty header, then use of flat 2d variables is prohibited.
If flat variables are disabled, 2d-variables are transformed into a single column, row above row, so that the former example should be written as follows:

The property makes the provider to save multidimensional variables as flat variables. But it doesn't affect loading process which thus can has variables in both representations. Also, flat variables can be enabled in the only case if all variable have display names, otherwise an exception will be thrown during save process.
The URI of CsvDataSet supports special parameter "flatVariables" which can be either "true" or "false" which initializes the property at construction.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.CSV.CsvDataSet.AppendMetadata
member.summary: Gets or sets the value indicating whether the metadata table is appended to the output file or not.
member.remarks: If the property is set, the provider saves to the end of an output file special metadata tables which can be a reason of incompatibility for some CSV-oriented programs. In the case you should set it false. If this property is changed, it starts a transaction to make it possible to save the data set through the Commit() method.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.CSV.CsvUri.OpenMode
member.summary: Gets the open resource mode.

remarks.para: The property gets the value representing the flag "openMode" in the data set URI.
The flag "openMode" specifies how the data set should open a file, data base or whatever resource it uses to store the data.

Possible values for the flag are (case-sensitive):
Mode Description
createNew Specifies that the data set should create new resource. If the resource already exists, an exception IOException is thrown.
open Specifies that the data set should open an existing resource. If the resource does not exist, an exception ResourceNotFoundException is thrown.
create Specifies that the data set should create a new resource. If the resource already exists, it will be re-created.
openOrCreate Specifies that the data set should open a resource if it exists; otherwise, a new resource should be created.

example.code: DataSet dataSet = DataSet.Create("msds:csv?file=data.csv&openMode=open");

member.name: T:Microsoft.Research.Science.Data.NetCDF4.NetCDFDataSet
member.summary: A provider that wraps the NetCDF4 interface.

remarks.para: The provider requires a managed NetCDF.Interop.dll library (either x86 or x64 version, depending on the platform) to work. The current Scientific DataSet release runtime package includes netcdf4.dll built from Unidata's source codes for NetCDF Release 4.1.3 with statically linked satellite libraries (including HDF5 1.8.7). (Default chunk cache size is 32 Mb, number of elements is 1009 and preemption policy is 0.75.)
The provider supports variables of any non-negative rank.
The provider is associated with the provider name "nc" and extensions ".nc".

accepts following parameters in the URI (read about DataSet URIs here: ; about preliminary URI customization ):
Parameter Description
file=path_to_file Specifies the file to open or create.
openMode=createNew|create|open|openOrCreate|readOnly
The flag "openMode" specifies how the data set should open a file, data base or whatever resource it uses to store the data. Possible values for the flag are:
Mode Description
createNew Specifies that the data set should create new resource. If the resource already exists, an exception IOException is thrown.
open Specifies that the data set should open an existing resource. If the resource does not exist, an exception ResourceNotFoundException is thrown.
readOnly Specifies that the data set should open an existing resource for reading only. If the resource does not exist, an exception ResourceNotFoundException is thrown.
create Specifies that the data set should create a new resource. If the resource already exists, it will be re-created.
openOrCreate Specifies that the data set should open a resource if it exists; otherwise, a new resource should be created.
If the input file is read only, the constructed data set is always read only. Consider cloning it into a to modify. See .
deflate=off|store|fastest|fast|normal|good|best
Defines the data compression level. Affects only new variables, added to the DataSet. Default is normal. Example: msds:nc?file=output.nc&openMode=create&deflate=good.
trimZero=true|false
Indicates whether the provider should trim trailing zero (\x00 symbol) when reads attribute values or not. This enables correct reading of attributes from NetCDF files created by C code with \x00 appended. Default is false.
enableRollback=true|false Indicates whether the rollback is enabled or not. If enabled, each transaction will lead to making a back-up of the underlying file for further possible restoration. If disabled, rollback will throw an exception when it is invoked. Set it for datasets having not only NetCDF variables and consider set it false to significantly increase performance. Default is true.
include Allows including variables as references from another , defined as a URI, into this . Example: msds:memory?include=msds%3Acsv%3Ffile%example.csv%23lat%2Clon (escaped version of "msds:memory?include=escape[msds:csv?file=example.csv#lat,lon]") includes variables lat and lon from msds:csv?file=example.csv. If variables names are not specified, all variables are included.
The provider supports URIs containing a path and appended through '?' parameters: c:\data\air0.nc?openMode=open&enableRollback=false.

In a NetCDF4 file all variables are stored as a set of chunks. The chunk size must be specified for each new variable and it cannot be changed later. Both read/write performance and output file size depend on the selection of the chunk size. Too small or too large chunks or wrong shape of a multidimensional chunk, relatively to the actually stored array's size and shape, can decrease performance and increase output file size. The chunk size selection algorithm, which is implemented in the , is aimed at a general case, therefore we define square chunks with size providing good performance and file size when storing arrays with length from 0 to about a million of elements. The algorithm parameters are based on empirical analysis. In short, the chunk size for each dimension is selected in a way to make total chunk size in bytes from 8 Kb to 128 Kb maximum; if it is impossible, chunk size in bytes must be the greatest possible, but less than 8 Kb.
If you need performance tuning, or you have a stretched array which doesn't fit well into square chunks, you should manually set the chunk size. To enable it, implements the interface.
Names. If a variable name is not complied with NetCDF naming rules, its simplified version is used at the NetCDF layer, but through the it is still visible unmodified.

support. Since the unmanaged NetCDF4 doesn't support a date/time type, it is internally stored as a double variable with special attribute Units = "100-nanosecond intervals that have elapsed since 12:00:00 midnight, January 1, 0001". NetCDF variables with this attribute are loaded as variables. In the current release, any other units descriptions are not considered as a date/time and hence the variable's final type of data is .
implements interface , therefore it allows a user to choose size explicitly. See remarks for the fore details.

There is an issue in the current version of NetCDF library: when defining a variable depending on a new dimension with name equal to a name of already existing variable, it fails. The only known solution is first to define the variable with this dimension, and then the variable with that dimension's name.
